page.title: 10LOCAL HISTORY
page.content: When the Normans arrived in Ulster they made use of the established rath on which to build a fortress. The Motte is 35 feet high and was a vital link in the chain of forts built by the Normans to keep the area in subjection. There are no traces of the forts, so it was probably a wooden structure. The fortress was destroyed in the fourteenth century when Edward Bruce invaded Ulster. The modern history of Dundonald dates from the Anglo Scots plantations of Ulster in the seventeenth century. A Scot called James Hamilton acquired Dundonald by dubious means and a village grew up round the "green".
